result.execSummary:
The defendant Ricky A Glenna was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Ricky A Glenna is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Ricky A Glenna was found guilty of Battery [Modifiers: Repeater, Domestic Abuse], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Def to undergo Alcohol and Drug Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommendations.
.

Def is not to consume or possess any alcohol or controlled substances without a prescription from licensed physician, with random testing

No Contact with Tiffany D. or her residence unless PO feels it is appropriate

No Contact with Mary Q or the 400 block of 4th St. in La Crosse WI
.

Complete a Domestic Abuse assessment and follow-through with any treatment recommendations

Complete any other assessments deemed appropriate by the PO and follow-through with any treatment recommended

Attend Domestic Review on 11-25-14 at 4:00 pm in Br 5

Pay Crime Lab and Drug Assessment fee (see 'other' above for amount)

9-23-14 CASH BOND IS NOT APPLIED - CRT ORDERED TO REFUND BOND - SEE ASSESSMENT REPORT

Pay DOC Supervision fees

If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of resititution victims and/or govermental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt
.

Pay restitution and 10% surcharge - held open for 45 days to determine amount

Restitution will be paid under the terms of a payment plan to be established with the PO but calling for no less than 2.5% of gross wages to be paid  toward restitution and to be enforced through a wage assignment
.

timeConds.notes:
The balance of the sentence can be served on Electronic Monitoring with Justice Sanctions
.

2:43 pm Def in court w/Atty Jennifer S Kovari.  Jessica Skemp appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

JS violations-  Kovari reads letter from Gundersen Lutheran about his diabetes...   Skemp:  The deluted samples are more recent.  Court:  He was testing positive and then starting showing up for tampering.   Skemp:  Diabetes does not rule out intentional tampering.  I know 2 prior drug court participants that didn't have controlled diabetes.  Neither one had tampering issues...   I think the circmstances of the tampering are more telling...  Kovari:  He did admit to drug usage last week when we were here.  Submits 8 letters from Dr. regarding ongoing issues...   I told Mr. Glenna that if there's an ongoing issue, he can't come to court again to address this.  I told him there would be consequences...   It is what it is and he's followed through with what he's going to do.  He's had problems going to work lately.  He says he's feeling and doing a lot better.
COURT:  He needs to provide a copy of this letter to JS>  I'm reluctant to throw him in jail when there's another medical explanation for this...  You're never going to get anywhere in recovery unless you're honest...   Glenna comments further.   COURT will not throw you in jail...
from Justin R., AMS of WI    re: compliance

JS violations--  positive tests and tampering.  Kovari did speak to Mr. Glenna about the violations.  He's on a financial restraint and wasn't able to take the full amount of his meds... I need to follow with the Dr. to get documentation for JS.  Court addresses Mr. Glenna.
